newsitem.title: UK: FORECAST - UK PPI to sound no inflation alarms.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - UK PPI to sound no inflation alarms.

text.p: British producer prices will continue to display no signs of pipeline inflationary pressures in August, analysts said on Friday.

A Reuter poll of economists forecast unchanged output prices in July, leaving them 2.0 percent higher than a year ago. Seasonally adjusted input prices are seen 0.3 percent higher on the month, leaving them 2.2 percent lower year-on-year. "The good inflation news seen from the start of the year looks set to last for some time yet," said Philip Shaw, group economist at Union Plc.
The data are due at 0830 GMT on Monday.

Economists said attention would focus on the output price figures which revealed a fall of 0.1 percent in the core measure in July for the first time since 1973, while the annual rate of 1.5 percent was the lowest recorded since November 1967.
Falling raw material costs and slower unit wage cost growth will continue to depress core output price inflation.
"With upstream price pressures still weak and manufacturing only just starting to recover, further declines in output price inflation seem likely," said economists at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.

On the input price side, economists said the hefty declines seen in recent months may well now be over. But with the year-on-year rate still well in negative territory, that will hardly constitute an inflation risk.
"Commodity prices have troughed, the oil price is firmer and manufacturers are now under less pressure to discount excess stock," said the Deutsche Morgan Grenfell analysts.

Economists discounted the effect of movements in oil prices, following U.S. missile attacks on Iraq, on input prices. "Oil prices were on a rising trend anyway, registering a near five percent increase in sterling terms during August," Shaw said.
Signs from recent data that the manufacturing sector could be past the worst will not derail the prevailing low inflation trend this year, economists said.
"The ratio of stocks to output remains at high levels and competitive pressures in the sector remain strong," Shaw said.

Simon Briscoe, UK economist at Nikko Europe, said Thursday's report from the Confederation of British Industry, which revealed a surge in British retail activity, was not a cause for concern for producer price inflation either.
Briscoe pointed to the wholesalers component which revealed that the orders and business outlook had not improved at all over the last six months.
"If you find that wholesalers aren't benefitting yet from the pick-up in retail demand then manufacturers are one step further back down the train," Briscoe said.
The CBI said retail sales volume rose again in August and the balance of firms reporting an increase in business was the largest since November 1988.
Briscoe added that manufacturing output, out on Friday, was unchanged in the quarter to July versus the previous quarter and was 0.1 percent lower than in the same quarter a year ago.
